<author>Cabanac, M., Cabanac, J. &amp; Paren, A.</author> <date>(2009).</date> <title>The emergence of consciousness in phylogeny.</title> <journal>Behavioural Brain Research,</journal> <volume>2(198),</volume> <pages>267-272.</pages> <note>[In this paper, the authors argue that consciousness evolved once, in amniotes. They support this with comparative behavioral and physiological data, and a functional/structural theory of consciousness which claims that consciousness is an integrative representational system for selecting actions based on expected hedonic consequences.]</note>
<author>Carruthers, P.</author> <date>(1989).</date> <title>Brute experience.</title> <journal>The Journal of Philosophy,</journal> <volume>86(5),</volume> <pages>258-269.</pages> <accessed>Retrieved from: http://www.jstor.org/stable/2027110.</accessed> <note>[Based on the idea that there are plenty of experiences that are unconscious and hence, to appeal to Nagel's formulation, not like anything, it is argued that what makes a nonconscious mental state conscious is its availability to be thought about by a higher order state. This dispositionalist account is distinguished from Armstrong's higher-order account based on the world-directedness of the former and the self-directedness of the latter. Carruthers also argues that his account implies that most other animals, with the possible exception of some higher mammals such as chimpanzees, lack conscious experience. Accordingly, it is deemed unnecessary and even unethical to have a concern for their pain.]</note>
<author>Carruthers, P.</author> <date>(1998b).</date> <title>Animal Subjectivity.</title> <journal>Psyche,</journal> <volume>4(3),</volume> <pages>2377.</pages> <accessed>Retrieved from: http://www.theassc.org/files/assc/2377.pdf.</accessed> <note>[see also “Replies to Critics: Explaining Subjectivity”, (his response to commentators), in Psyche, 6 (3)]</note>

<section>11</section> <genre>bibliographie</genre> <title>Books on Poultry, a collector of bibliography</title> <note>PALMER J. ANG</note> <date>2003</date> <note>LG SELBY LTD ( NZ ) 5</note> <title>planches photographiques en couleurs reproduisant</title> <unknown>le</unknown> <title>1er plat de couverture d’ouvrages majeurs. Contient 434 auteurs et liste environ 1000 titres et éditions sur les volailles (poules, canards, oies, pintades, paons…). Très jolie couverture souple illustrée en couleurs. Excellent travail dans lequel l’auteur note avec justesse qu’il a pu inclure certains titres qui ne l’avaient jamais été dans les précédentes bibliographies. (Pour exemples, un titre de STURGES* et un autre de HICKS*, un ouvrage de PALTHE* qui rend hommage à l’éminent et regretté collectionneur et artiste néerlandais</title> <note>VAN GINK*). #H:\BASES_DE_DONNEES\REF11.DOC#</note>
